TI Correlation between biological and physical availabilities of
   phenanthrene in soils and soil humin in aging experiments
SO ENVIRONMENTAL TOXICOLOGY AND CHEMISTRY
LA English
DT Article; Proceedings Paper
CT Symposium on Mechanisms and Effects of Resistant Sorption Processes of
   Organic Compounds in Natural Particles, at the 214th National Meeting of
   the ACS
CY 1997
CL LAS VEGAS, NV
SP Amer Chem Soc, Environm Chem Div
DE sequestration; aging; desorption kinetics
ID DISTRIBUTED REACTIVITY MODEL; ORGANIC-CHEMICALS; AROMATIC-HYDROCARBONS;
   BIOAVAILABILITY; SORPTION; BIODEGRADATION; DESORPTION; SEQUESTRATION;
   SEDIMENTS; SOLIDS
AB The bioavailability of an organic compound in a soil or sediment commonly declines with the soil-chemical contact time (aging). A series of parallel desorption and bioavailability experiments was carried out on phenanthrene previously aged up to similar to 100 d in Mount Pleasant silt loam (Mt. Pleasant, NY, USA) or Pahokee peat soil to determine as a function of the aging period the degree of correlation between the reduction in bioavailability and the rate and extent of desorption and the influence of soil organic matter composition on availability. The mineralization of phenanthrene by two bacteria and the uptake of phenanthrene by earthworms showed expected declines with aging. Likewise, the rate of phenanthrene desorption in the absence of organisms decreased with aging. The decline in initial rate of mineralization or desorption was nearly an order bf magnitude after 50 to 60 d of aging. Plots of normalized rates of mineralization or desorption practically coincided. Similarly plots of normalized fraction mineralized or fraction desorbed during an arbitrary period gave comparable slopes. The partial removal of organic matter from the peat by extraction with dilute NaOH to leave the humin fraction reduced the biodegradation of phenanthrene aged for 38 and 63 d as compared to the nonextracted peat,but the effect disappeared at longer incubation times. The rate of desorption from samples of peat previously extracted with NaOH or Na4P2O7 declined with aging and, for a given aging period, was significantly slower than from nonextracted peat. This work shows that the reduction in bioavailability of phenanthrene over time in soil is directly correlated with reduction of its physical availability due to desorption limitations. In addition, this study shows that removal of extractable humic substances leads to a decline in the rate of desorption and, in the bioavailability of the substrate.

AU FOSTER, TV
   HAYES, MHB
   WASE, DAJ
AF FOSTER, TV
   HAYES, MHB
   WASE, DAJ
TI EFFECTS OF NATURALLY-OCCURRING IRON-CARRIERS ON CONTINUOUSLY CULTIVATED
   ESCHERICHIA-COLI
SO JOURNAL OF BIOTECHNOLOGY
LA English
DT Article
DE IRON-TRANSPORT; METAL ION-TRANSPORT; HUMIC MATERIAL; FULVIC ACID;
   CONTINUOUS CULTIVATION
ID TJEUKEMEER NETHERLANDS; INTRACELLULAR SODIUM; WATERS; POTASSIUM; GROWTH
AB Previous work has shown that when fulvic acid, which occurs naturally in Birmingham tap-water, is extracted and added, along with iron, to continuous cultivation media, the mean cell volume increases with agitation rate at constant dilution rate.  The organic material appears to act as an iron-carrier.  These effects are examined in more detail in the present paper in which the effects produced by tap-water are compared with those produced by peat extracts.
   The fulvic acid extracted from Birmingham tap-water was compared with fulvic acid extracted from peat.  Both materials produced volume increases in continuously cultivated cells in the presence of iron, and it was concluded that both were effective as iron-carriers.  Direct aqueous extracts of peat also proved very active in this respect.
   Use of radioactive iron as a tracer showed that the amount of iron associated with the continuously cultivated microbial cells increased with increase in agitation rate in both tap-water based medium and in distilled water based medium containing peat extracts, whereas no such increase was observed in the case of distilled water based control medium.  It is concluded that the distribution of such natural iron-carriers of this type is quite widespread, and that they are involved in mechanisms of iron uptake and extraction for a wide range of living organisms.

TI Dissolved organic matter degradation by sunlight coagulates
   organo-mineral colloids and produces low-molecular weight fraction of
   metals in boreal humic waters
SO GEOCHIMICA ET COSMOCHIMICA ACTA
LA English
DT Article
DE Photodegradation; Arctic; Iron; Organic carbon; Trace element;
   Complexation; Size fractionation
ID RARE-EARTH-ELEMENTS; IRON REDOX TRANSFORMATIONS; FIELD-FLOW
   FRACTIONATION; TRACE-ELEMENTS; PHOTOCHEMICAL TRANSFORMATION; TEMPORAL
   VARIATIONS; SIZE FRACTIONATION; RICH NANOCOLLOIDS; INORGANIC CARBON;
   ALASKAN RIVERS
AB Photochemical degradation of dissolved organic matter (DOM) is recognized as the major driver of CO2 emission to the atmosphere from the inland waters of high latitudes. In contrast to numerous studies of photo-induced DOM transformation, the behavior of trace element (TE) during photodegradation of boreal DOM remains virtually unknown. Towards a better understanding of concentration, size fractionation and speciation change of DOM and TE in boreal waters subjected to solar radiation, we conducted on-site photo-degradation experiments in stream and bog water collected from a pristine zone of the Northern Karelia (Russian subarctic). The removal of Fe and Al occurred only in the bog water (90% and 50% respectively, over 5 days of reaction), whereas no detectable decrease of dissolved (<0.22 mu m) Al and Fe concentration was observed in the boreal stream. A number of low-soluble TE linked to Fe-rich organo-mineral colloids followed the behavior of Fe during bog water exposure to sunlight: Al, P, Ti, V, Cr, As, Y, Zr, REEs, Hf, Th, Pb and U. The second group of elements (Li, B, Mg, Ca, Sr, Ba, Na, K, Rb, Si, Mn, Ni, Cu, Co, Cd, Sb) was indifferent to photodegradation of DOM and exhibited a non-systematic variation (+/- 10-15% from the control) of < 0.22 mu m fraction in the course of sunlight exposure. The bog water insolation yielded a factor of 3 perpendicular to 1 increase of low molecular weight (LMW < 1 kDa) fraction of organic carbon, Al, Fe, U, Mg, Ca, Mn, Co, Ni, Sr, Cd and Ba after 200 h of sunlight exposure compared to the dark control. The LMW< 1 kDa fraction was preferentially enriched in Fe, Al, Ca, Mg and other divalent metals relative to Corg. The climate warming leading to water temperature rise in the boreal zone will intensify the Fe and Al hydroxide coagulation while increasing the production of LMW organic ligands and free metals and metal-organic complexes. (C) 2017 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
